title: 108_s759
content: The Act titled "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" introduces a credit for residential wind energy property under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act introduces a credit for residential wind energy property, allowing a 30% credit on qualified expenditures. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications for eligibility. Unused credits can be carried forward. Safety certifications are required for property to qualify for the credit. Any excess credit can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Qualified wind energy property expenditures are defined in this section. Qualified wind energy property expenditure is defined as an expenditure for qualified wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence by the taxpayer. Any excess credit can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Qualified wind energy property expenditure includes expenses for wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence by the taxpayer, including installation fees. The property must be a qualifying wind turbine with the original use starting with the taxpayer and a minimum 5-year lifespan. "Qualified wind energy property refers to a qualifying wind turbine with a 5-year limited warranty for defects in design, material, or workmanship, and installation." A qualifying wind turbine of 75 kilowatts or less must have a 5-year limited warranty for defects in installation. Expenditures for labor costs related to the onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified wind energy property and for interconnecting such property to the energy grid are considered for this section. Labor costs must be properly allocable to qualify. Expenditures for labor costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified wind energy property and interconnecting it to the energy grid are considered for this section. Labor costs must be properly allocable. Swimming pools, hot tubs, or other energy storage mediums with functions other than storage are not included in this section. Special rules apply for jointly occupied dwelling units. Special rules apply for jointly occupied dwelling units, where the amount of the credit allowable for expenditures made by any individual with respect to the dwelling unit is determined by treating all occupants as one. The credit allowable for expenditures made by individuals with respect to a jointly occupied dwelling unit is determined by treating all occupants as one taxpayer for the taxable year. Each individual is eligible for a credit in proportion to the total amount determined for the group. The credit for expenditures made by individuals in a jointly occupied dwelling unit is determined by treating all occupants as one taxpayer. Each individual receives a credit based on their proportion of total expenditures made by all occupants. Individuals in a jointly occupied dwelling unit receive a credit based on their proportion of total expenditures made by all occupants. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations and members of condominium management associations are also eligible for certain tax benefits. Individuals who are members of a condominium management association are treated as having made their proportionate share of the association's expenditures. The term 'condominium management association' refers to an organization that meets specific requirements for a condominium project where most units are used as residences. If less than 80 percent of qualified wind energy property is used for nonbusiness purposes and energy generation for sale, certain allocations apply. The term 'condominium management association' refers to an organization that meets specific requirements for a condominium project, with most units used as residences. Allocation rules apply if less than 80 percent of qualified wind energy property is used for nonbusiness purposes and energy generation for sale. Expenditure for qualified wind energy property is considered when installation is completed and property is used for energy generation. Expenditures for building construction are treated as made when the structure is used by the taxpayer. The amount of any expenditure is the cost thereof. Property financed by subsidized energy financing affects the amount of expenditures made for any dwelling unit. For determining expenditures on a dwelling unit, costs from subsidized energy financing are not considered. Basis adjustments are made if a credit is allowed for qualified wind energy property expenditures. The credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures reduces the basis increase of the property. This section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit can be used against regular tax and alternative minimum tax, with a limitation based on the amount of tax. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures has a limitation based on the amount of tax, which includes the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55. The credit cannot exceed the total of these taxes minus the sum of other allowable credits for the taxable year. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures is limited by the total of regular tax liability and tax imposed by section 55. The credit cannot exceed the total of these taxes minus the sum of other allowable credits for the taxable year. Amendments are made to sections 25C and 23(b)(4)(B) of the tax code. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code, including inserting "subsection (b)(3)" in section 23(b)(4)(B) and adding "section 25C" in section 24(b)(3)(B). Section 25(e)(1)(C) is amended to include "25C," and section 25B(g)(2) now includes "sections 23 and 25C." Section 25(e)(1)(C) of the tax code is amended by inserting "25C," after "25B," while sections 25B(g)(2), 26(a)(1), 904(h), and 1400C(d) are also updated to include references to section 25C. Section 1400C(d) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include references to section 25C, along with other conforming amendments to sections 23(c) and 25(e)(1)(C) for taxable years before January 1, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include references to section 25C and make conforming amendments to sections 23 and 25 for taxable years before January 1, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include references to section 25C and make conforming amendments to sections 23 and 25 for taxable years before January 1, 2004. Additionally, amendments are made to section 1400C(d) and the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by section 25C for residential wind energy property apply to expenditures after December 31, 2002, in taxable years ending after that date. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a credit is provided for business installation of small wind energy property. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. This applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. The definition of qualified wind energy property is expanded to include turbines installed on farms, ranches, or eligible small businesses in the United States. The amended Internal Revenue Code includes qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009 for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. This includes turbines on farms, ranches, or eligible small businesses in the US, owned and used by the taxpayer with a 5-year warranty. The qualified wind energy property must have a 5-year limited warranty covering defects in design, material, workmanship, and installation. The tax credit for such property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to the lesser of certain amounts. The tax credit for wind energy property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity for qualifying wind turbines. The tax credit for wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity for qualifying wind turbines of 75 kilowatts or less meeting performance standards. The tax credit for wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity for qualifying wind turbines of 75 kilowatts or less meeting performance and safety standards set by industry associations. The tax credit for wind energy property is limited to 30% for qualified wind energy property and 10% for other energy property. There is a conforming amendment related to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit for wind energy property is limited to 30% for qualified wind energy property and 10% for other energy property. A conforming amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is made regarding the effective date for property placed in service after December 31, 2003.
